item.dc:creator: admin

item.content:encoded:
Key Details

  • Programme: ITLOS – Nippon Foundation Capacity-Building and Training Programme on Dispute Settlement under UNCLOS

  • Location: Hamburg, Germany

  • Duration: July 2026 – March 2027 (9 months, full-time)

  • Funding: Fully funded (travel, accommodation, medical insurance, and monthly allowance)

  • Application Deadline: 6 March 2026

  • Eligibility: Junior to mid-level government officials and researchers, mainly from developing countries

  • Age Requirement: 25–40 years

  • Language: English and French (programme mainly conducted in English)

Overview

In cooperation with the Nippon Foundation, the Tribunal runs an annual capacity-building and training programme on dispute settlement under the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (‘UNCLOS’).

The full-time programme, which runs for nine months and begins in July each year, takes place at the seat of the Tribunal in Hamburg, Germany. Contingent upon the availability of funds, a call for applications is generally announced each year during the month of January or February.

The programme is aimed at junior to mid-level government officials and researchers mainly from developing countries who are currently working on issues related to the law of the sea, maritime law or dispute settlement. It provides participants with a unique opportunity to develop their legal skills and deepen their practical knowledge of dispute settlement in the law of the sea under UNCLOS.

All participants’ costs, including travel, accommodation, medical insurance and a monthly allowance, are covered by the Nippon Foundation.

  • Flyer

Lectures

A series of lectures takes place throughout the nine months of the programme. Lectures are generally held over the course of two days, offering the fellows the possibility of close debate with the lecturers. The faculty of lecturers is drawn from Judges of the Tribunal, Registry officials, United Nations and international organizations, universities, law firms and other relevant institutions.

At the beginning of the programme, the fellows take part in the four-week Summer Academy of the International Foundation for the Law of the Sea. This course focuses on law of the sea and maritime law and is attended by around 40 young professionals from around the world working in the fields of law of the sea and maritime law.

Some examples of lectures given during recent programmes are:

Dispute settlement under UNCLOS

  • The mechanism for the settlement of disputes under Part XV of UNCLOS with a special focus on ITLOS
  • Contentious and advisory proceedings
  • Giving evidence before international courts and tribunals
  • Provisional measures
  • Prompt release

International organizations and the law of the sea

  • The role of international organizations in the implementation of UNCLOS
  • The work of the Division for Ocean Affairs and the Law of the Sea, Office of Legal Affairs, United Nations
  • The mandate and work of the Commission on the Limits of the Continental Shelf under UNCLOS
  • The interaction between the International Seabed Authority and the Tribunal

Current issues related to the law of the sea

  • Law of maritime delimitation
  • Law of the sea and human rights
  • The Arctic and UNCLOS
  • The establishment of the limits of the continental shelf
  • Fisheries management
  • Marine scientific research
  • Marine biological diversity of areas beyond national jurisdiction

International environmental law

  • General principles of international environmental law
  • UNCLOS and the regional seas programmes
  • The precautionary principle and the protection of the marine environment
  • Climate change and the law of the sea
  • Biodiversity and protection of ecosystems

Maritime law lecture series

  • Maritime security
  • Ship registration
  • Vessel pollution

International law lecture series

  • Sources of international law
  • law of international organizations
  • State responsibility
  • Law of treaties

Training

Training sessions and workshops are arranged in order to enhance the practical and professional skills of the fellows.

The programme offers training in negotiation and mediation. Workshops are organized to prepare the fellows for their potential role as agents, counsel, or legal advisers in cases before international courts and tribunals. The tools used for this purpose include exercises in drafting documents relating to cases, attendance at oral proceedings at the Tribunal, the International Court of Justice or the Permanent Court of Arbitration, and presentation skills using audio-visual tools.

Collaborating institutes

An integral part of the training and capacity-building programme on dispute settlement under UNCLOS is the cooperative arrangement with Max Planck Foundation for International Peace and the Rule of Law in Heidelberg, Germany, and the Norwegian Centre for the Law of the Sea in Tromsø, Norway. Cooperation is undertaken in the following areas:

  • Max Planck Foundation for International Peace and the Rule of Law in Heidelberg, Germany: training on conflict resolution and visits to the library of the Max Planck Institute for Comparative Public Law and International Law.
  • Norwegian Centre for the Law of the Sea in Tromsø, Norway: discussions and training on the law of the sea and visits to relevant institutions.

Study visits

Group visits of between two and five days complement the knowledge gained and training given in dispute settlement and issues/topics related to the law of the sea. Accompanied by a legal officer, the fellows are given exclusive access to experts from the institutions and have the chance to attend hearings or meetings.

In previous years, the following visits have been organized for the fellows:

Belgium: Brussels

  • European Commission’s Directorate-General for Maritime Affairs and Fisheries

Germany: Berlin, Bremen, Cuxhaven, Hamburg, Hanover, Kiel

  • Alfred Wegener Institut
  • Federal Coastguard
  • Federal Institute for Geosciences and Natural Resources
  • Federal Maritime Hydrographic Agency
  • GEOMAR Helmholtz Center for Ocean Research Kiel
  • Hamburg Port Authority
  • Maritime Safety and Security Centre

Italy: Rome

  • Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations

Switzerland: Geneva

  • The United Nations Office at Geneva
  • Geneva Center for International Dispute Settlement

The Netherlands: The Hague

  • International Court of Justice
  • International Criminal Court
  • Permanent Court of Arbitration

United Kingdom: London

  • International Maritime Organization
  • International Oil Pollution Compensation Funds
  • OSPAR Commission

Research

Research on law of the sea disputes and other ocean matters relevant to governments and institutions of the participants is an integral part of the training. After a training session on legal research methodology, the fellows undertake research using the library facilities of the Tribunal. Participants undertake their research under the guidance and supervision of the Registry. Participants have also the opportunity to refer questions concerning their research topics to the Judges of the Tribunal. The results of the research are presented to the Judges of the Tribunal at the end of the programme.

Eligibility

  • Applicants must be between the ages of 25 and 40.
  • Applicants must have a first university degree in law and demonstrate a capacity to undertake independent scientific research, study and training.
  • Applicants must be:
  1. Junior to mid-level government officials from an administration or government agency, dealing with ocean affairs or maritime matters as well as legal issues relating thereto; or
  2. Researchers from an institute (academic or government) dealing with ocean-related or maritime matters as well as legal issues relating thereto.
  • Applicants must indicate the research topic which they intend to pursue during the programme. The research topic should address legal issues of relevance to the State and institutions of the participants regarding the implementation of UNCLOS, in particular Part XV thereof.
  • The administration or institute nominating the applicant must indicate on the nomination form the tasks performed by the applicant and explain the extent to which the training programme will benefit the institution/State concerned.
  • Applicants must have an excellent knowledge of one of the official languages of the Tribunal (English and French) and a working knowledge of the other language. The lectures and activities of the Programme are mainly held in English.

Procedure

The following documents must be submitted in order for an application to be processed:

  • Fellowship Application Form to be duly completed, signed and submitted by the applicant.
  • Nomination Form to be duly completed, signed and directly submitted by the nominating agency. The submitted form must be typed.

In the case of government officials, the nominating agency should be a relevant governmental body. For researchers, the nominating agency may be the institute or academic department of the university to which they are affiliated.

Nominating agencies are invited to submit two copies of the Nomination Form:

  1. One scanned version of the signed original; and
  2. One electronic version.

The Nomination Form should preferably be sent by e-mail to training@itlos.org, by fax to: +49 40 35607-245, or by post to:

Office of the Registrar
International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea
Am Internationalen Seegerichtshof 1
22609 Hamburg
Germany

Conditional acceptance to the programme

Admitted applicants must submit the following documents:

  1. A medical certificate issued by a duly qualified physician stating that they are in good health and fit to complete the entire programme (from July 2026 until March 2027). The certificate must indicate that the admitted applicant is able to travel inside Germany and overseas.
  2. A certificate issued by the nominating agency indicating that the candidate is granted permission to travel to Hamburg and to participate in the full nine-month programme from July 2026 to March 2027.

Final admission to the programme will be contingent upon submission of the medical and permission certificates. Admitted applicants must submit a copy of the certificates within two weeks of announcing the admission. The original certificates must be submitted on the first day of the programme and must be in either English or French or accompanied by a certified translation.

Participants’ costs, including travel, accommodation, medical insurance and a monthly subsistence allowance, are covered by the Nippon Foundation.

Participants are responsible for obtaining a visa for Germany for the period of the programme at their own cost, although assistance may be provided in order to facilitate the visa application process.

During the programme, the fellows become part of the ITLOS community and are fully integrated in the life of the Registry for nine months. They interact with staff, Judges and participants of the other training programmes run at the Tribunal. As ITLOS alumni, the fellows join a growing network of young professionals from around the world working in the field.

Fellows are provided with a fully equipped office with computer, printer and internet connection for the duration of the programme. Fellows have access to the Tribunal’s specialized Library, which houses a comprehensive collection on the law of the sea and related subjects, such as maritime law, environmental law, ocean affairs, coastal management, international courts and tribunals, international organizations, dispute settlement, arbitration, and general issues of public international law.

Accommodation in the vicinity of the Tribunal is provided in studio apartments, with a bedroom/sitting area, kitchen and bathroom.

During their first weeks in Hamburg, the fellows are introduced to life in Germany and given German language classes. Language training in French may also be provide

For further information please contact:

The ITLOS-Nippon Programme Coordinator
International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea
Am Internationalen Seegerichtshof 1
22609 Hamburg
Germany

Tel.: (+49) 40 35607-243
Fax: (+49) 40 35607-245
training@itlos.org

Source: https://www.itlos.org/en/main/the-registry/training/itlos-nippon-foundation-capacity-building-and-training-programme/

item.content:encoded:
Applications for the Manaaki New Zealand Scholarships will open on March 1, 2026. Funded by the Government of New Zealand, these fully funded scholarships support applicants from eligible countries to undertake full-time postgraduate studies in 2027.

This prestigious program aims to build leadership capacity and contribute to sustainable development in partner countries.

Scholarship Overview

The Manaaki New Zealand Scholarships provide full financial support for selected international students pursuing postgraduate qualifications in New Zealand.

Priority Sectors

Applicants must align their proposed studies with one of the following priority development areas:

  • Climate resilience, science and environment

  • Economic resilience and the private sector

  • Food security and agriculture

  • Governance

  • Infrastructure

  • Peace, security and justice

  • Resilient societies

Programs of study should clearly demonstrate how they contribute to development outcomes in the applicant’s home country.

Eligible Educational Institutions

Scholarship recipients may study at the following New Zealand institutions:

  • Auckland University of Technology

  • Lincoln University

  • Massey University

  • University of Auckland

  • University of Canterbury

  • University of Otago

  • University of Waikato

  • Victoria University of Wellington

  • Southern Institute of Technology

  • Unitec Institute of Technology

Applicants must apply to eligible programs offered at these institutions.

Who Can Apply?

Applicants must:

  • Be from an eligible country

  • Apply for full-time postgraduate study (Master’s or PhD level)

  • Demonstrate alignment with priority development sectors

  • Meet academic and English language requirements

  • Intend to return to their home country after completion

Key Dates to Remember

📣 Applications Open: March 1, 2026
⏳ Applications Close: March 30, 2026

Late applications are not accepted, so early preparation is strongly advised.

Application Period

🗓 March 1 – March 30, 2026

item.content:encoded:
The Transatlantic Future Leaders Forum (TFLF) is a prestigious internship platform designed to give the brightest Polish university students an opportunity to gain hands-on experience in the offices of top lawmakers in Washington, D.C. and London.

Through this program, participants are immersed in transatlantic policymaking environments, working alongside decision-makers and gaining valuable insights into legislative processes in both the United States and the United Kingdom.

Beyond the internship experience, TFLF provides a robust support and mentoring structure for talented students, helping them build professional skills, expand their networks, and prepare for leadership roles in public life.

What TFLF Offers

TFLF is more than an internship—it is a comprehensive leadership development platform that equips participants with knowledge, exposure, and connections.

Participants benefit from:

  • Internships with leading policymakers in the U.S. Congress and the UK House of Commons

  • Mentorship and career support from experienced professionals

  • Exclusive meetings with leaders in politics, academia, and business

  • Exposure to think tanks, companies, and professional service organizations in both countries

  • A strong network of high-achieving Polish peers and alumni

The program is built and led by former interns of U.S. Congress and the UK Parliament who are committed to creating opportunities for the next generation of Polish leaders.

Vision and Mission

The Transatlantic Future Leaders Forum aims to:

  • Connect exceptional Polish students with open-minded and influential decision-makers in Washington and London

  • Provide educational and professional development opportunities through real-world policy experience

  • Build a strong network of future Polish leaders equipped with international perspectives

  • Foster long-term collaboration between Polish scholars and global institutions

Through its programming, TFLF serves as a bridge between academic excellence and real-world policymaking.

Why Apply to TFLF?

The Transatlantic Future Leaders Forum offers a rare opportunity to:

  • Gain real-world experience in global policymaking

  • Learn directly from influential lawmakers and institutions

  • Build a competitive international profile

  • Join a prestigious network of future Polish leaders

For ambitious Polish students passionate about public policy, international relations, and leadership, TFLF is a transformative stepping stone toward a global career.

Application Process

1. Online Application

To apply for the 2026 summer internship program, candidates must complete the official online application form.

Deadline: 31 March 2026 (23:59 CET)

Applicants should prepare the following before starting the application:

  • Answers to assessment questions (in plain text format)

  • Personal details and availability information

  • Updated CV

Note: The application form cannot be saved midway, so all required information must be ready before starting.

Applicants seeking guidance can attend an online information session (date to be announced), with registration details available on the program’s website.

2. Oral Examination (Assessment Centre)

Shortlisted candidates will be invited to an Assessment Centre in Warsaw, where they will participate in:

  • An interview

  • Practical exercises conducted in English

The program committee will evaluate candidates based on their overall performance and recommend top applicants for internship placement.

3. Final Candidate Selection

Recommended candidates will have their applications forwarded to participating Members of Parliament and Members of Congress.

Each office may:

  • Conduct its own internal review

  • Invite candidates for an additional phone interview

Successful applicants will be notified by TFLF once their placement is confirmed with a specific office.

Key Deadline

  • Application Deadline: 31 March 2026 (23:59 CET)

Start your journey toward transatlantic leadership with TFLF and become part of the next generation shaping the future of global policy.

Discover more Internship Opportunities Here

item.content:encoded:
Are you looking to launch your career inside one of the world’s most prestigious luxury maisons? Hermès, the iconic French house founded in 1837, is offering multiple paid, full-time internships for 2026 across its Communication, Marketing, Finance, Quality, Product Development, and Retail Education departments.

These six-month internships, primarily based in Paris, Pantin, Fontenay-sous-Bois, and surrounding Île-de-France locations, provide exceptional hands-on experience within a global luxury group employing more than 25,000 people worldwide.

Hermès is recognized for its craftsmanship, creativity, entrepreneurial spirit, and commitment to excellence. Interns will work alongside experienced professionals in a dynamic, high-performance environment that values ethics, diversity, inclusion, and responsible management.

All internships are full-time and paid, lasting six months. Start dates vary between July and September 2026 depending on the position.

About Hermès: A Global Leader in Luxury Craftsmanship

Hermès is a French, family-owned, and independent company with nearly two centuries of heritage. The House operates across sixteen artisanal métiers, producing leather goods, fashion accessories, crystal, jewelry, saddlery, ready-to-wear, and more.

With nearly 300 stores worldwide, Hermès maintains a unique artisanal model rooted in local production in France, respecting both people and nature.

These internships are hosted within Hermès International (the holding company), Hermès Sellier, Hermès Manufacture de Métaux, and Cristallerie Saint Louis.

Why Apply to Hermès Internships?

  • Work within a globally respected luxury maison

  • Gain hands-on experience in real projects

  • Build international exposure

  • Develop technical, analytical, and creative skills

  • Strengthen your professional network in luxury, communication, finance, and innovation

Hermès promotes ethics, diversity, inclusion, and equal opportunity.

Overview of Available Hermès Internships 2026

1. Assistant Press Officer (Accessories) – Paris

Location: Paris
Duration: 6 months
Start: Second half of 2026

Within the Press/Influence Department, interns will support media and influencer relations strategy.

Key Responsibilities:

  • Preparing, sending, and managing press samples for French and international distribution

  • Coordinating with media outlets and influencers (print, TV, radio, digital)

  • Supporting press events and ensuring media coverage

  • Managing communication between subsidiaries and internal departments

Profile:

  • Student in Communication/Public Relations

  • Strong organizational skills

  • Fluent English

  • Proficient in Word, Excel, Internet tools

  • Appreciation for high-end products

Learn more HERE.

2. Assistant Project Manager – Institutional Communication (Advertising Campaigns) – Paris

Location: Paris
Duration: 6 months
Start: Second half of 2026

This role supports paid advertising campaigns including cross-business campaigns, holiday campaigns, and store openings.

Responsibilities:

  • Coordinating with advertising agencies and subsidiaries

  • Managing campaign timelines and budgets

  • Designing editorial pages for hermes.com

  • Overseeing styling logistics and production

  • Managing digital and print deliverables

  • Preparing campaign reports

Profile:

  • Business/Communication school student

  • Prior internship experience in agency or corporate communications

  • Fluent English

  • Skilled in PowerPoint, Excel, Word

  • Strong project management skills

Learn more HERE.

3. Operational Marketing Assistant – Cristallerie Saint Louis (Pantin)

Location: Pantin
Start: July 2026
Duration: 6 months

Saint-Louis creates exceptional handcrafted crystal pieces.

Responsibilities:

  • Supporting sales promotions, trade shows, and events

  • Developing communication materials

  • Coordinating window display adaptations internationally

  • Supporting video content creation

  • Monitoring sales tools and promotional materials

Profile:

  • Marketing student

  • Proficient in PowerPoint & Excel

  • Fluent English

  • Interest in interior design and lifestyle

Learn more HERE.

4. Assistant Management Controller – Finance (Île-de-France)

Locations: Pantin, Fontenay-Sous-Bois, Bobigny
Duration: 6 months
Start: Second half of 2026

Responsibilities:

  • Supporting budget review and financial closing

  • Preparing Excel and PowerPoint financial reports

  • Developing performance indicators

  • Conducting benchmarking analysis

  • Assisting in cross-functional financial projects

Profile:

  • Finance or Business School student

  • Strong Excel skills

  • Analytical mindset

  • Prior experience in management control preferred

Learn more HERE.

5. Quality Assistant – Hermès Manufacture de Métaux (Fontenay-sous-Bois)

Location: Fontenay-sous-Bois
Start: September 2026
Duration: 6 months

Responsibilities:

  • Supplier monitoring and audit prioritization

  • Implementing Master Data management tools

  • Developing quality documents

  • Creating KPIs

  • Supporting continuous improvement initiatives

Profile:

  • Engineering student (Master’s level)

  • Knowledge of manufacturing processes

  • Excel, Power BI proficiency

  • Fluent English

Learn more HERE.

6. Development Assistant Project Manager – Jewelry Leather & Enamel Division (Pantin)

Location: Pantin
Start: September 2026
Duration: 6 months

Responsibilities:

  • Managing prototype and runway schedules

  • Coordinating suppliers and production sites

  • Monitoring product development phases

  • Managing reporting and inventory updates

  • Supporting podium campaign execution

Profile:

  • Business or Engineering student

  • Interest in Supply Chain

  • Strong Excel & PowerPoint skills

  • Highly organized and adaptable

Learn more HERE.

7. Retail Education Assistant – Fashion Accessories (Pantin)

Location: Pantin
Start: September 2026
Duration: 6 months

Responsibilities:

  • Developing product training materials

  • Creating e-learning modules

  • Organizing international Train The Trainers seminars

  • Designing creative educational tools

  • Supporting internal communications

Profile:

  • Master’s-level student

  • Fluent English

  • Strong PowerPoint skills

  • Retail experience valued

  • Creative and organized

Learn more HERE.

Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ)

Are Hermès internships paid?

Yes. All listed internships are paid and full-time for six months.

Where are the internships located?

Primarily in Paris and the Île-de-France region including Pantin, Fontenay-sous-Bois, and Bobigny.

Who can apply?

Students enrolled in undergraduate (rising junior or above), Master’s programs, or recent graduates depending on role.

Is English required?

Yes. Most roles require fluency in English (written and spoken).

Are beginners accepted?

Yes. Beginners are accepted, though prior internship experience is valued for some roles.

Do I need to send both a CV and cover letter?

Yes. Applicants must submit both documents and specify availability.

Visit HERE to find more information about the Hermès Internships 2026 in Paris.

item.content:encoded:
If you are a Malawian development professional eager to advance your career in global development, peace, security and governance, this is one of the most prestigious and high-impact scholarship opportunities available this year.

About the Programme — MSc in Global Development

This Master of Science (MSc) in Global Development focuses on building skills that strengthen:

• Peace and security
• Development policy analysis
• Governance and leadership in development settings

It is delivered via distance learning, meaning you can continue working and contributing to your community while pursuing your studies.

The course is taught by The Open University and delivered in partnership with Civil Society Agriculture Network (CISANET) in Malawi.

What’s on Offer?

The Commonwealth Distance Learning Scholarships have awarded five fully funded awards worth £90,000 to support Malawian nationals to study for the highly respected MSc in Global Development delivered by The Open University (U.K.)

Why This Scholarship Matters

• Fully funded scholarships (tuition covered)
• Study a globally recognised Master’s degree from a top UK distance-learning institution
• Continue working at home while studying part-time
• Become a leader in development policy, peace, governance and security
• Make a measurable impact in your community and country

This programme has supported over 220 East African professionals to date.

Benefits

Here’s what the scholarship includes:

1. Full tuition fee coverage for the MSc
2.  Ability to study part-time via distance learning
3.  A Master’s degree from a respected UK university
4.  Enhanced skills in development policy, governance, peace and security
5.  Boosted professional credibility and career prospects

Note: Scholarships generally cover tuition only; living costs are your responsibility.

Eligibility Criteria

To be considered for one of the five Commonwealth Scholarships, applicants must:

1.  Be Malawian nationals
2.  Be employed by a development agency (government, NGO or private sector) in Malawi
3.  Have at least two years of professional experience working on development issues in Malawi
4.  Hold a good undergraduate degree (preferably in a relevant development field)
5.  Demonstrate a strong commitment to local and national development goals
6.  Meet scholarship and degree entry requirements set by the Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office (FCDO) and CSC.

This scholarship is designed for professionals with leadership potential and practical experience.

Application Process

To apply:

Step 1 — Create a CSC Account

Go to the Commonwealth Scholarship Commission (CSC) application portal and sign up.

You will find the eligible course “MSc Global Development (distance learning)” listed under Group 4: Strengthening global peace, security and governance.

Step 2 — Complete the Online Application Form

Apply here

Important: Provide a detailed explanation of how your degree will benefit Malawi. This narrative is a key part of the selection process.

Step 3 — Submit Before Deadline

Submit all required materials before 16:00 GMT, 31st March 2026.

Important Dates & Deadlines

Deadline Detail
31st March 2026 – 16:00 GMT Final deadline to submit the scholarship application online.
October 2026 Expected programme start date for MSc in Global Development scholars.

Pro Tip: Submit early — late or incomplete applications will not be considered.

This is a rare and highly competitive scholarship for development professionals in Malawi — one that can truly elevate your career and multiply your impact back home.

For more information visit here

item.content:encoded:
The David McClure Public Interest Journalism Fellowship is a prestigious, fully funded opportunity designed to support independent, non-fiction writers and journalists producing rigorously researched public interest journalism. From 2026, one Fellow per year will receive £15,000 to complete an investigation that holds power to account and serves the public good.

Presented by the Oxford International Centre for Publishing (OICP) at Oxford Brookes University, this Fellowship honours the legacy of acclaimed investigative journalist David McClure, whose work exposed centuries-old institutional privilege and reshaped public understanding of royal wealth and power.

About David McClure

David McClure was a highly respected journalist, news producer, and author whose career was defined by deep forensic investigation and public accountability journalism. Over a decade, he uncovered how the British Royal Family’s private estates and investments were shielded from scrutiny for centuries.

His investigations resulted in two landmark non-fiction books—Royal Legacy: How the Royal Family Have Made, Spent and Passed on Their Wealth (2014) and The Queen’s True Worth: Unravelling the Public & Private Finances of Queen Elizabeth II (2020). These works were serialised in the UK press, described as “bombshell revelations”, and covered extensively by global media. McClure passed away from cancer in June 2022.

Why This Fellowship Matters

Funding for investigative journalism has been under sustained pressure for more than a decade. The 2019 Cairncross Review highlighted the growing financial fragility of public interest reporting—an issue that remains unresolved today.

The David McClure Public Interest Journalism Fellowship directly addresses this challenge by providing dedicated financial support for investigations that are:

  • Time-intensive

  • Costly to research

  • Independent of political or commercial influence

  • Essential to the public domain

Without this Fellowship, many such investigations might never be completed or published.

Fellowship Overview

  • Award Amount: £15,000

  • Number of Fellows: 1 per year

  • Duration: Five years (2026–2031)

  • Start Date: September each year

  • Funded By: David McClure Trust Fund

  • Host Institution: Oxford International Centre for Publishing (OICP)

The Fellowship supports the completion of a single, long-form piece of public interest journalism with strong contemporary relevance.

What Type of Journalism Is Supported?

The Fellowship is intentionally flexible, with minimal restrictions. However, the proposed investigation must be:

  • Original

  • Non-fiction

  • Non-biased and non-partisan

  • Rigorously researched

  • Of clear public interest and contemporary relevance

The selection panel’s primary consideration is how deserving the investigation is to be in the public domain.

Key Benefits of the Fellowship

  • £15,000 in dedicated funding

  • Institutional support from Oxford Brookes University

  • Recognition associated with David McClure’s investigative legacy

  • Time and financial freedom to complete ambitious journalism

  • Increased likelihood of publication and impact

Eligibility and Qualifications

  • Open to journalists, authors, and non-fiction writers worldwide

  • No restrictions on:

    • Age

    • Nationality

    • Background

    • Career stage

  • Diversity is welcomed, but merit and public value are the deciding factors

Can I Apply If My Investigation Is Already Underway?

Yes. The Fellowship is specifically designed for writers who have begun an investigation but cannot progress or complete it without financial support.

Can I Apply If I Haven’t Started Yet?

The Fellowship prioritises projects already in progress. Applicants must demonstrate research undertaken and progress to date.

Financial Need and Use of Funds

Applicants will not be means-tested. However, applications must clearly explain:

  • Why Fellowship funding is essential to complete the investigation

  • How the £15,000 will be used (e.g. research time, travel, data access, legal review, archival work)

The panel will prioritise public value over personal financial circumstances.

Selection Panel

The Fellow will be chosen by a panel comprising:

  • Members of the Oxford International Centre for Publishing (OICP)

  • Selected experts from its Publishing Advisory Board

  • Selected experts from its Journalism Advisory Board

Panel members include publishers, literary agents, journalists, authors, and senior industry professionals.

Application Requirements

Applicants must submit a 1,500-word pitch that includes:

  1. Synopsis of the investigation

  2. Aims and objectives

  3. Public interest relevance

  4. Key research undertaken so far

  5. Progress to date

  6. Why Fellowship support is essential

  7. Detailed explanation of how funds will be used

Shortlisted applicants will be invited to an online interview.

Deadlines and Key Dates

  • Application Deadline: 31 May (annually)

  • Interview Period: Summer

  • Fellowship Start Date: September

  • Frequency: Once per year, for five consecutive years starting in 2026

How to Apply

Applications must be submitted via the official application form:

Apply here

(Shortlisted candidates will be contacted directly for interview details.)

The David McClure Public Interest Journalism Fellowship is a rare and powerful opportunity for writers committed to truth, accountability, and public value. If you are pursuing an investigation that matters—but lack the resources to finish it—this Fellowship exists to make that work possible.

For more information visit here

item.content:encoded:
Global technology leader Apple Inc. is now offering multiple Finance Internship opportunities for students passionate about building careers in finance, analytics, and business strategy.

This highly competitive internship provides hands-on experience within Apple’s Finance organization and a potential pathway into the prestigious Finance Development Program (FDP).

If you are targeting a career in corporate finance, financial analysis, or data-driven business strategy, this is an opportunity to work at one of the most influential companies in the world.

About the Apple Finance Internship

Apple’s Finance Internship allows students to work alongside top finance professionals while supporting key areas of the business.

Interns may be placed within departments such as:

  • AppleCare

  • Financial Services

  • Internet Software & Services

  • Marketing

  • Operations

  • Research & Development

  • Retail

  • Sales

  • Worldwide Financial Planning & Analysis

  • And more

During the internship, participants contribute directly to real business projects that impact Apple’s global operations.

What You’ll Do as a Finance Intern

As an intern, you will gain exposure to advanced financial and analytical work, including:

  • Conducting in-depth financial analysis using advanced Excel functions

  • Working with SQL and data tools

  • Creating dashboards using data visualization platforms such as Tableau

  • Designing and optimizing data-driven reporting systems

  • Building automated financial models and reporting solutions

  • Collaborating with cross-functional teams to deliver strategic insights

  • Identifying operational efficiencies through analytics and technical platforms

This internship is structured to help students develop technical, analytical, and business communication skills at a world-class level.

Pathway to the Finance Development Program (FDP)

Successful summer interns may become eligible to join Apple’s Finance Development Program (FDP).

The FDP is a 12–18 month rotational program designed for entry-level finance talent. Participants typically rotate across four to six finance functions, gaining broad exposure across Apple’s business.

Upon completion of the FDP, participants transition into permanent Financial Analyst roles within Apple.

This internship is therefore not just a summer role — it can serve as a launchpad for a long-term finance career at Apple.

Minimum Qualifications

Applicants must:

  • Be pursuing a Bachelor’s degree in:

    • Finance

    • Data Science

    • Mathematics

    • Statistics

    • Business Administration

    • Economics

    • Accounting

    • Or a related field

  • Have an expected graduation date of Winter 2027 or Spring 2028

Application materials must include:

  • Resume

  • Cover letter

  • Unofficial transcript

Applications without these documents will not be considered.

Preferred Qualifications

Strong candidates will demonstrate:

  • Advanced Excel proficiency

  • Experience with SQL or Python (preferred but not required)

  • Strong analytical and problem-solving skills

  • Ability to thrive in fast-paced and ambiguous environments

  • Excellent written and verbal communication skills

  • Curiosity, initiative, and accountability

Why You Should Apply

This internship offers:

  • Exposure to Apple’s global finance operations

  • Hands-on experience with advanced financial analytics

  • Cross-functional collaboration experience

  • Mentorship from leading finance professionals

  • A potential pathway into Apple’s Finance Development Program

  • Career acceleration within a globally recognized technology company

Apple is committed to inclusion and diversity and provides equal opportunity to all qualified applicants.

How to Apply

To apply, submit:

  • Resume

  • Cover letter

  • Unofficial transcript

For more information click here 

Apply here 

Early application is strongly encouraged due to the competitive nature of the program.

Discover more opportunities here

item.content:encoded:
The AI Skills 4 Women program is a free, fully online course designed to equip women with practical artificial intelligence skills — no technical background required. This initiative is delivered by Founderz in collaboration with Microsoft to help close the gender gap in AI and technology.

If you’re looking to enter the AI space or strengthen your digital skills, this short but impactful program is worth exploring.

What You’ll Learn

Participants will gain foundational and practical knowledge in:

✔️ AI Fundamentals
✔️ Practical AI Applications
✔️ Prompt Engineering & AI Ethics
✔️ AI Cybersecurity & Data Analytics
✔️ Leadership & Mentorship Skills

The course is structured to be accessible, even for beginners with no prior technical experience.

Program Details

✅ Duration: 3 Hours
✅ Mode: 100% Online
✅ Credential: Official Microsoft Certificate
✅ Additional Benefit: Opportunity to win AI scholarships

The short format makes it ideal for students, professionals, entrepreneurs, and career switchers who want to quickly build AI literacy.

Who Should Enroll?

This program is open to:

  • Women interested in technology and AI

  • Students exploring digital careers

  • Professionals looking to upskill

  • Entrepreneurs integrating AI into their work

  • Career switchers entering tech

No prior coding or technical background is required.

Why This Matters

Women remain underrepresented in AI and emerging technologies. Programs like AI Skills 4 Women aim to increase participation, confidence, and leadership in the digital economy.

By completing this course, participants gain both technical awareness and strategic insight into how AI is transforming industries worldwide.

How to Enroll

Enroll for free and begin your AI learning journey here.

item.content:encoded:
The LEAP Advance Leadership Development Program is an intensive leadership initiative designed to support higher education professionals in strengthening their leadership capacity and advancing their influence within academic institutions.

Delivered in partnership with the Asian Pacific Americans in Higher Education (APAHE), the program prepares participants to lead with confidence through an Asian and Pacific Islander (API) cultural lens.

This program is ideal for professionals seeking greater visibility, executive presence, and leadership effectiveness in colleges and universities.

About LEAP Advance

LEAP Advance is a structured leadership development experience tailored specifically for professionals working in higher education.

Through culturally responsive leadership training and mentorship, participants gain the tools needed to navigate institutional structures, enhance executive presence, and expand their professional influence.

The program centers leadership development within the context of Asian and Pacific Islander identities, perspectives, and lived experiences, fostering both personal growth and systemic impact.

Curriculum Highlights

The LEAP Advance curriculum is designed to provide both practical leadership skills and identity-based empowerment.

Key components include:

Culturally Responsive Leadership Development
Participants explore leadership frameworks that integrate cultural identity and institutional dynamics.

One-on-One and Small Group Mentoring
Structured mentoring provides individualized support and professional guidance.

Mock Interviewing Practice and Executive Presence
Hands-on sessions help participants refine communication, confidence, and interview readiness for senior roles.

Engagement with Senior Higher Education Leaders
Interactive sessions with senior administrators and college presidents offer insight into executive-level leadership.

Key Outcomes

Participants in LEAP Advance can expect:

  • Enhanced leadership capacity within academic institutions

  • Increased self-awareness of cultural leadership identity

  • Strengthened executive presence and communication skills

  • Expanded professional network within higher education

  • Greater visibility and readiness for senior leadership roles

This program is particularly impactful for professionals aiming to advance into administrative, executive, or institutional leadership positions.

Why You Should Apply

If you are a higher education professional seeking to:

  • Strengthen your leadership competencies

  • Lead authentically through a culturally grounded lens

  • Expand your professional network

  • Prepare for senior-level roles in academia

LEAP Advance offers a targeted pathway to elevate your influence and long-term career trajectory.

How to Apply

Interested applicants should visit the official program page through the organizing institution to access the application details and submission link.

Apply here

item.content:encoded:
The Secretariat of the Convention on Biological Diversity under the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) is now accepting applications for a six-month internship focused on traditional knowledge and engagement with indigenous peoples and local communities.

This opportunity is linked to preparations for major Convention on Biological Diversity processes, including COP17 and the Nature and Culture Summit. The internship can be undertaken at the Montreal duty station in Canada or remotely.

The application deadline is March 7, 2026.

About the UNEP Internship 2026

Hosted by the United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP), this internship supports work under the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD). The selected intern will contribute to biodiversity governance efforts that integrate culture, indigenous knowledge systems, and environmental sustainability.

The internship provides emerging professionals with exposure to multilateral environmental negotiations and global biodiversity policymaking in preparation for COP17.

Internship Location

  • Montreal, Canada (Duty Station)

  • Remote option available

This flexibility allows eligible candidates worldwide to participate without relocation, depending on arrangements.

Internship Focus and Responsibilities

The intern will support research, drafting, and coordination activities related to biodiversity, culture, and traditional knowledge systems.

Key responsibilities include:

  • Conducting research on biodiversity, indigenous peoples, and traditional knowledge

  • Drafting background documents and meeting materials

  • Supporting coordination with stakeholders and indigenous representatives

  • Assisting in preparations for COP17 discussions

  • Contributing to engagement processes linked to the Nature and Culture Summit

This role provides hands-on experience in global environmental governance and collaboration with indigenous communities at the international level.

Language Requirements

  • Fluency in English (oral and written) is mandatory

  • Knowledge of French and/or Spanish is considered an asset

Financial Information

This internship is unpaid.

Interns are responsible for:

  • Travel arrangements

  • Visa costs

  • Accommodation

  • Living expenses

The United Nations does not charge any fees at any stage of the recruitment process.

Eligibility Criteria

Applicants must meet one of the following academic requirements:

  • Be enrolled in or have completed a Master’s or PhD programme

  • Be in the final year of a Bachelor’s degree

  • Have recently completed a Bachelor’s degree

Candidates should demonstrate:

  • Academic background in environmental studies, indigenous studies, law, public policy, or related disciplines

  • Strong analytical and writing skills

  • Knowledge of indigenous peoples, traditional knowledge, or biodiversity governance

  • Computer literacy in standard software tools

  • Interest in multilateral environmental processes

  • Ability to work across diverse cultural contexts

  • Alignment with the values of the United Nations

Professional work experience is not mandatory, but relevant academic specialization is required.

Why You Should Apply

This internship is ideal for students and recent graduates interested in:

  • Global biodiversity governance

  • Indigenous knowledge systems

  • Environmental law and policy

  • Multilateral negotiations

  • International environmental diplomacy

It offers rare exposure to international policy processes leading up to COP17, making it a valuable stepping stone for careers in environmental governance and global development.

How to Apply

Interested applicants should scroll to the official link provided by the host institution and submit their application before the deadline.

The final date to apply is March 7, 2026.

Early submission is strongly recommended.
